author: hustla187
title: Good Mini
review: Lego made a good mini set right here. This is a mini TIE fighter. I like the detail of this even though it is a mini set. If you owned other minis this would be good too. Lego might bring these back soon and it's because of this.

author: water_jedi_17
title: more better than the original
review:
As my title states, this is better than the original TIE fighter. At the bottom are the pros and cons.
 The TIE is connected by a long technic piece that keeps it from breaking easily, unlike the original. Just like the original, it uses the transparent dish piece as the cockpit. The wings are larger compromising of five pieces. The pieces look scaled down compared to the wings of the larger TIE.
  Pros:
more details
strong pieces
more pieces
 Cons:
lacks laser cannons but after all, it is a mini so itâ€™s not much of a problem

author: stu241273
title: Playable mini, very sturdy, an inexpensive treat!
review:
You should know before I start, that I'm not a huge fan of mini or midi sets.  This however is one of the better minis I have.  It's perfect for smaller hands to grab and swoosh around, and it really is very sturdy once built - it can stand quite a bit of throwing around and trampling.


The shape is good, well representative of the original Tie Fighter from the original trilogy.  Colours are off - which is a consistent issue with Tie Fighters, but that just doesn't detract from the enjoyment of building and playing with the set.


I love the clear dish used for the cockpit window.


As this was given away free, or part of a newspaper promotion, I don't think there can be any cause to gripe about the price.  And it makes for an inexpensive stocking filler.

author: Cal_Zagy
title: A Good Little Mini Set
review:
This set came with the Daily Record [65p] today. Price to pieces ratio is brilliant.
Is much more sturdy than the original mini tie fighter (and the mini tie advanced which had a tendency to break easily). It is also quite a lot larger than the older mini sets which I owned (4484 and 4487). 

Pros:
-More sturdy
-Cheap
-Lots of good parts
-Nicely detailed for a MINI set 

Cons:
-Can't think of anything

author: thewish
title: (Screech of TIE coming past)
review:
This set came with a Daily Mirror promotion and is virtually free. The set is very detailed for a Mini set and is great against the Rebel fighters.

PROS-
Very detailed
Playability is great
Cheap

CONS-
Wings can spin round if piece holding it to the central column loosens

A little set thats great for all ages.

author: fatpretzel
title: Best mini TIE Fighter yet
review:
I found this set at Walmart for $3.97. Very cheap for current Lego prices. It went together very well and should be very durable. 

Pros

  • Very detailed for a mini set. The wings are much closer to the right shape and the grill pieces give it a nice trim.

  • Very durable. The axle through the center of the set makes it very solid even if dropped.

Cons

  • With all mini sets, the price per piece is very high at $0.09 per piece.

  • I have never liked the TIE fighter in the black with blue trim. It should be light gray with black wings.
Looks very nice on display. Easy to build and ver durable even for youngsters. A ver good set for eveyone's collection.

author: Huge_Nerd
title: Classic polybag
review: I got this set at a Walmart in 2012.  This set has been around for years, it seems, and it definitely shows its age compared to more recent Star Wars offerings.  It has the blue that Lego seemed fond of using with Imperial vehicles in the past, and it has a less smooth look than recent sets.  That being said, it gets the job done and makes a nice opponent for the polybag X-Wing. Overall, I'm glad I got it.

author: Odeinoichus
title: Packaging Variants Be Aware
review:
Set #8028 Mini TIE-Fighter: Polybagged enthusiasts rejoice, a limited edition set has been made available in new 2012 packaging in Canada. Originally created and released in 2008 LEGO has re-packaged this model in a new package featuring the 2012 Darth Maul look and made it available in Canadian TRU stores.

This little model is perfect, it is a TIE Fighter perfectly to scale with similar fighters in the Planet Set and Polybagged line of Mini Starfighters. The model is a fast, fun build and once you're done you have a swishable little TIE to fly around your room, lair or other place of residence. There are no really unique parts or printing for this set and it does include the typical TIE Fighter Blue for the model, easily replaceable parts in dark gray, light gray or silver if you prefer to change up the color scheme. I don't mind.

Overall a great little ship, perfect for sitting on your desk at home or your desk at work, grab two or more if you can and you'll have a small squad of TIEs in no time. It's also great for Brick Films and Dioramas.

author: Cbl
title: Hours of fun
review: This may be nostalgia taking over, but this set is amazing. When I was in elementary school, my parents bought this for me. It's a very simple, easy build, and most builders can complete it in under 10 minutes. This is my favorite polybag ever released, because I played with this for hours. And I mean hours. Swooshing this around the living room was a lot of fun as a kid. A great value for your buck! Kids will love this. I still have it built (unlike most of my polybags/battlepacks) and it remains one of my favorite sets in my collection.

author: Slobrojoe
title: An old TIE in a new(er) poly bag
review:
The TIE Fighter is one of the most iconic and recognisable Star Wars ships ever. In my opinion, it would be third on the most iconic Star Wars ships list after the first place Millennium Falcon and the second place X-wing. Just to give you an idea of how famous this set in LEGO is, I'm going to put it up against the Millennium Falcon on the 'microscale' factor. The Millennium Falcon features in 7 microscale sets: 2 Microfighters (one with Chewie and the other with Han); 1 in-store Toys R Us build; 2 magazine gifts; and 3 standard polybags. Comparatively, the standard TIE Fighter alone features in 8 microscale sets; 1 Microfighter; 5 standard polybags; 1 magazine gift; and 1 in-store Toys R Us build. That is pretty impressive. 

Now I've got the stats out the way, I'll link in my second and third picture reviews because I may refer or compare to them in this video.

30276: First Order Special Forces TIE Fighter- https://brickset.com/reviews/56345

30275: TIE Advanced Prototype- https://brickset.com/reviews/56358 

Without further ado, I shall start my fourth picture review!

P.S. I'm sorry about the black-on-black photos!

Availability:

This set was available in the UK via The Sun newspaper on Sunday the 27th of May, 2008. It was also available in the UK when customers ordered a bundle of £50 or more from Lego.com during March 2012. In the US, the set could be purchased at Target in 2013. Finally, it was given away at the LEGO Club Day at LEGOLAND Germany in October 2008.

Packaging/Instructions:

This set came in a polybag, but I no longer have it for photography purposes. If you're desperate, the standard Brickset image is basically the whole of the polybag. The instructions are a fold-out leaflet featuring a total of eight easy to follow steps. There are two things that strike me as different from the other two TIEs I reviewed (see links above). Firstly, the picture of the completed model that you can find on any Star Wars polybags is on the right-hand side, rather than the left, as with the other poly bags I have reviewed. Secondly, the new parts that are placed on the build each time have their part numbers to the side of the step.

 

Parts:

44 pieces are used in the model. The pieces aren't very rare but the rarest piece is the blue 2x4 plate with three holes down the middle, which appears in a total of 39 sets. The main colours are blue and black, which take on the colour scheme left off from the TIEs between 1999 and 2004. After that, there's nothing special about these parts.

The Build:

The build is separated into three parts: the main body, the left wing and the right wing. The build is very simple, even for beginners, taking no longer than three minutes. The main body is set upon an axle, just like the First Order Special Forces TIE Fighter. The wings are assembled in practically the same way as its First Order counterpart, just with slightly more pieces involved.

The Completed Model:

Let me roll off some pictures.

The wings are adorned with blue grills and a 2x2 round plate, which fits the axle on. Whilst the First Order TIE uses big gear wheels between the body and the wings, this one uses only small grey nuts. The cockpit lacks detail but gives the ship a sort of rustic feel, whilst the same technique is utilised in the TIE Advanced Prototype, it isn't as complimentary. Maybe a touch more blue would have been ideal to make this set a little more like the bigger sets from 1999. 

Price: 

In the US, the set would set you back a whopping $5, whilst a Sun newspaper would have been about £4, which I think is a more reasonable price point. 

Overall Opinion: 

I really like this set, and it takes a proud place upon my Kallax IKEA shelves. Although 8028 doesn't trump others in the facts of price, parts, playability or building experience, it is a truly wonderful display piece. My only downside is the slight lack of blue. It works especially well against the original black and blue TIEs, but I have mine on display with my First Order Special Forces TIEs.

I hope this review was helpful and look out for some more of my picture reviews in the near future.

-----
